entry.title: Replication in critical graphs and the persistence of monomial ideals
entry.summary: Motivated by questions about square-free monomial ideals in polynomial rings, Francisco et al. [Discrete Math. 310 (2010), 2176-2182] conjectured that for every positive integer k and every k-critical (i.e., critically k-chromatic) graph, there is a set of vertices whose replication produces a (k+1)-critical graph. (The replication of a set W of vertices of a graph is the operation that adds a copy of each vertex w in W, one at a time, and connects it to w and all its neighbours.) We disprove the conjecture by providing an infinite family of counterexamples. Furthermore, the smallest member of the family answers a question of Herzog and Hibi concerning the depth functions of square-free monomial ideals in polynomial rings, and a related question on the persistence property of such ideals. As an aside, we give a simple direct proof of the result of Francisco et al. that their conjecture holds for graphs whose fractional chromatic number exceeds k-1.
